title: Devon MP says campaign of intimidation by Brexit extremists is “misleading and very toxic” - Devon Live
text:
Devon MP says campaign of intimidation by Brexit extremists is “misleading and very toxic” Sarah Wollaston: I have always said I would respect the result of the referendum Share Get Daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Devon MP Sarah Wollaston has branded a campaign of intimidation against her as “misleading and very toxic”. 
Dr Wollaston, the MP for Totnes, has been targeted by Brexit extremists since she was dubbed a “mutineer” by the Daily Telegraph. 
She said yesterday that she would not be intimidated by the “wall of aggression”. 
Dr Wollaston was one of 15 Conservative MPs who privately expressed concerns to the Conservative Party Whips’ office about the Prime Minister’s plan to set in stone the date Britain leaves the EU, regardless of the state of trade negotiations. 
The Daily Mail followed up with an attack on the MPs, and they were also targeted on social media by a paid-for advertising campaign. The misleading Daily Telegraph front page 
The adverts were posted by a murky Florida-registered organisation calling itself “Brexit Realities”. The group has been linked on social media to a former Vote Leave campaigner Thomas Borwick and his lobbying company Voter Consultancy Ltd. 
We have left a message for Mr Borwick to get in touch to explain the campaign, but have not heard back. 
Dr Wollaston said that, as a result of the campaign, her office had inundated by “a wall of aggressive correspondence”. 
“I voted Remain, but have always said I would respect the result of the referendum,” she said. “I think it’s right that MPs should express any concerns they have. 
“I did privately express my concerns about setting a hard date, which wasn’t in the original Brexit Bill.” 
She said negotiations sometimes go to the wire, and that “setting a hard date runs the risk that at the 11th hour we will need emergency legislation to repeal it”. Read More 
“I was unhappy to find that a private conversation ended up with me being the subject of such hostile briefing. 
“There are consequences of using this kind of language. 
“There is no evidence that I am betraying Brexit by trying to press for better legislation. If you are not prepared as an MP to scrutinise legislation, there is no point being here. 
She said that, unlike fellow MP Anna Soubry, she has not had death threats, but added: “My team has had to deal with a wall of aggressive correspondence. 
“But I refuse to be intimidated. As a colleague said, if you climb high mountains, expect high winds.” 
Dr Wollaston said she would also oppose so-called Henry VIII powers for ministers after Brexit. The government has said it wants to be able to amend legislation introduced to replace EU laws, without consulting Parliament. “Nobody voted to bring back powers from Brussels, only to see them taken over by a tiny group of ministers,” she said. 
Dr Wollaston has called for a new committee to be set up to “triage” secondary legislation after Brexit. Like us on Facebook
